description:
Trichodysplasia spinulosa-associated polyomavirus (TSPyV) is a small, non-enveloped DNA virus that belongs to the Polyomaviridae family. It was first identified in 2010 as the causative agent of a rare skin condition called trichodysplasia spinulosa, which primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.

The TSPyV genome is a circular, double-stranded DNA molecule of approximately 5.2 kilobases in length. The virus encodes several regulatory and structural proteins, including the large T antigen and small T antigen, which play crucial roles in viral replication and host cell manipulation.

Infection with TSPyV typically occurs through skin-to-skin contact or exposure to contaminated surfaces. The virus primarily targets the follicular keratinocytes of the skin, leading to the development of distinctive follicular papules and spiny projections, which are the hallmarks of trichodysplasia spinulosa.

The exact mechanisms by which TSPyV causes the clinical manifestations of trichodysplasia spinulosa are not fully understood, but it is believed that the viral proteins interact with cellular signaling pathways and disrupt normal skin cell differentiation and proliferation.

TSPyV is considered an emerging pathogen, and its prevalence and epidemiology are still being actively investigated. While the infection is relatively rare, it is essential for healthcare professionals to be aware of this virus and its associated clinical presentation, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, to ensure prompt diagnosis and appropriate management.
